case_vignette: A 62-year-old man with well-controlled rosacea, a monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL; stable on no current therapy) was seen in the clinic for a full-body skin check! Results of his examination were unremarkable except for the presence of periorbital, yellow-brown plaques with violaceous borders involving the upper and lower eyelids, bilaterally! There was induration, but no warmth or tenderness, of the periorbital plaques! He first noticed these lesions around the time he was diagnosed with CLL; initially they were more discrete yellow papules that developed into plaques over time! They are completely asymptomatic!
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
Hello! I don't have any symptoms; the issues on my upper and lower eyelids are completely asymptomatic.
Can you describe the appearance of the issues on your eyelids?
They are yellow-brown plaques with violet-colored borders on both my upper and lower eyelids.
Have you noticed these plaques increasing in size or number over time?
Yes, they started as more discrete yellow bumps and developed into plaques over time.
Do you have a personal or family history of high cholesterol or lipid disorders?
I don't know of any family history, and my medical information hasn't mentioned anything about high cholesterol or lipid disorders.
Have you experienced any other skin changes or systemic symptoms, such as joint pain or abdominal discomfort?
No, I haven't experienced any other skin changes or systemic symptoms like joint pain or abdominal discomfort.
Final Diagnosis: Necrobiotic xanthogranuloma.

trial_0.singleturn_mcq: Final Diagnosis: Adult-onset asthma with periocular xanthogranuloma
